THE LAST STAND

ΒΥ this, though deep the evening fell, Still rose the battle's deadly swell, For still the Scots, around their King, Unbroken, fought in desperate ring. Where’s now their victor vaward wing, Where Huntly, and where Home? O for a blast of that dread horn, On F ontarabian echoes borne, That to King Charles did corne, When Roland brave, and Olivier, And every paladin and peer, On Roncesvalles died! Such blast might warn thern, not in vain, To quit the plunder of the slain, And turn the doubtful day again, While yet on Flodden side Afar the Royal Standard flies, And round it toils, and bleeds, and dies Our Caledonian pride!

But as they left the dark'ning heath, More desperate grew the strife of death.
